text: Gabriel Manessy (March 28, 1923 – June 17, 1996) was a French linguist who worked on Niger-Congo languages, especially the Gur languages. Manessy is known for his historical-comparative work on the Gur languages.Manessy, Gabriel. 1979. Contribution à la Classification Généalogique des Langues Voltaïques. (Langues et Civilisations à Tradition Orale, 37.) Paris: Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique. He was written extensively on the Gurunsi,Manessy, Gabriel. 1969. Les Langues Gurunsi: Essai d'application de la méthode comparative à un groupe de langues Voltaïques. (Bibliothèque de la SELAF, 12, 13.) Paris: SELAF. Oti-Volta, and Senufo languages.Nicolaï, Robert (2001). "Hommage à Gabriel Manessy. Leçons d’Afrique : Filiations, ruptures et reconstitutions des langues, 7-9. Peeters. ==Career== Manessy was born on March 28, 1923. After studying literature, his interest shifted to ethnology. After working briefly at the CNRS, he taught linguistics at the Faculty of Letters of Dakar and became the first Director of the Centre de linguistique appliquée de Dakar (CLAD). He was appointed Professor in 1964. He supervised Masters students in African Linguistics, first at Dakar, then at the Faculty of Letters and Human Sciences at Aix-en-Provence. From 1969 to 1988, he taught at the Faculty of Letters and Human Sciences at the University of Nice. He retired in 1988. Manessy died on June 17, 1996 at the age of 73. ==References== ==External links== *Publications on Persée Category:1923 births Category:1996 deaths Category:Linguists from France Category:Linguists of Niger–Congo languages Category:20th-century linguists
